Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Exploring the Equatorial Solar Wind from Photosphere to Heliosphere Along Solar Cycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 2-year postgraduate research fellowship project which aims to provide improved understanding of how the slow and fast solar wind heating and acceleration occurs in response to the strength of the solar cycle. The research work will be conducted at the highly collaborative environment of the Atmospheric, Oceanic and Space Science Department at the University of Michigan. The PI will incorporate the research results into the undergraduate and graduate level courses in the University of Michigan. The PI is a recent PhD graduate and this research project will support the continued training and career advancement of an early-career female scientist in the Atmospheric and Geospace sciences. Therefore, the project will enhance the participation of women in sciences, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines.


This 2-year research project will uniquely combine the analysis of in-situ measurement of solar wind properties and of spectroscopic observations of solar wind source regions, taking advantage of the strengths of both types of observations and different analysis techniques. The empirical models to be derived from the matching of in-situ measurements and remote sensing observations will be unprecedented in their detail, and they will continuously cover the entire distance from the solar wind source region to the freeze-in height. These empirical models will provide a benchmark that will allow discrimination between competing solar wind heating and acceleration models and scenarios and will greatly advance our understanding of the solar wind phenomenon and its dependence on solar cycle phase and strength. Moreover, by using two different types of techniques and data, this research work will serve as a link between two Space Sciences communities, and the outcome of this project will benefit both sides.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 

The results of the funded project directly attack the most important questions concerning the origin of the slow and fast solar wind on the ecliptic at 1 AU. In order to achieve the scientific goals, we made a systematic use of two completely different diagnostic techniques: remote sensing and in situ measurements. This combination allowed us to obtain a most powerful analysis tool at our disposal with which we can reach a whole new level of understanding of the origin of the solar wind and its impact on the space weather. Our results provided valuable scientific preparation for the future analysis of the observations from Heavy Ion Sensor (HIS) onboard Solar Orbiter and provided a benchmark that would allow discrimination between competing slow solar wind heating and acceleration theories, and would help improve the accuracy of space weather predictions.

 

This project advanced the discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning. This project was conducted in the highly collaborative environment at the University of Michigan. With the undergraduate, master and Ph.D. students in space science, the Climate and Space Sciences and Engineering department of the University of Michigan is well positioned for integrating cutting edge solar physics research into education. The PI, Dr. Zhao and her sponsoring scientist, Dr. Landi have incorporated research results into the undergraduate and graduate level courses in the University of Michigan. For example, Dr. Zhao has served as a Co-advisor of an undergraduate student under the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program (UROP) for one year. In addition, Dr. Zhao has been helping prof. Lepri and prof. Landi mentor a graduate student of their research group. Dr. Zhao had strong records of both publishing in refereed journals as well as of presenting material at meetings (AGU, SHINE, etc.), and continued to be productive in this manner. For example, Dr. Zhao and her colleagues have written ten papers (six published, one accepted, two under review and one to be submitted soon) and two ACE news items. And she gave seven scientific presentations in international and national conferences, one of them was an invited talk, and organized and leaded a Session in the NSF SHINE workshop.  

 

This project broadened the participation of underrepresented groups. The PI, Dr. Liang Zhao, a female postdoc, received mentoring and career development through this project, so that this proposed work enhanced the participation of women in sciences, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. During the grant period, Dr. Zhao was selected as one of the ten winners of the Outstanding Postdoctoral Fellow Awards of the University of Michigan in the year of 2015 and was invited to give an oral presentation as one of the eight young leading scientists in the United States to the 2014 Inaugural Forum for New Leaders in Space Science (held by Chinese Academy of Sciences and U.S. National Academy of Sciences). In addition, Dr. Zhao has served as a proposal review panelist for four panels (three panels for NASA and one for NSF). Also, she has served as a professional reviewer for four journal papers and a mail-in reviewer for four NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship proposals. Therefore, the success of this project has helped Dr. Zhao gain visibility, experience and connections to establish her career as a woman in STEM disciplines.
